content.description: A great boulder for the micro-beta climber! Would not recommend if you are prone to shoulder injuries or re-injuries. This boulder starts on the far left of the face, and works right until you arrive at a slopey ledge hold. Then go for the top! Top out.
content.location: Located on the same face as 3-2-1 Contact.

content.description: Power your feet on and begin throwing, slapping and heel hooking along the lower lip till you can wrap around the end to top out.  Originally graded V8, it is now cleaner and stickier and appears to be easy for the grade.
content.protection: Rocky but mostly flat landing with a surprisingly small pad foot print.  Two or more pads will protect those nasty back slaps.
content.location: Not in the guidebook, you can find this route on the Studs Boulder right around the corner from Spear Point.  A beautiful overhanging prow that requires open handed upside down fridge wrestling technique.  Ooooohhhhh what fun!!  Begin with the left hand pinching or crimping the arete and the right hand fighting a slopey undercling pinch.

content.description: Start at the head height crimp in the center of the boulder
content.location: Keep moving west through Africa Area until you reach a more open area, and the boulder will be hard to miss on your right.

content.description: Begins on the rightmost side of the face. Start with a foot on the bulge and make your way up using the mini crack system up the right arete.
content.location: Located on the Ethiopian boulder. After walking east through Africa area for about 60ish feet you will arrive at a more open area. The boulder is on the right, and is very hard to miss.

content.description: Start on the low left side of the boulder and work up from a sloper and a sidepull. Moves slightly right and then straight up. Sit down start!
content.location: When you reach Ethiopian boulder (the boulder on the right when you reach an area with less trees) go around the left side and behind the boulder and you'll see the spot.

content.description: Start in the middle of the face, work pretty much straight up on crimps. Sit down start! Optional V4 dyno to the white colored ledge from the start.
content.location: On the westmost side of Africa (area), you'll reach a less covered area and the boulder will be on your right as you walk. [Will fix this description soon to be more accurate]

content.description: This route is fantastic but is held back by it's start. It starts on a flat, chalky sidepull that is angled just perfectly to make it terrible. This route moves up on the mini-arete on good crimps and ledges. Probably a V2- if you start with your left with the next hold. Sit down start!
content.location: Located on the right side of the Contact boulder's western face. Opposite side of the path from the Africa Boulder.

content.description: A burly pocket and crimpfest with cool footwork.  Used to be a touch easier until a generous round ball at the end of the crux section snapped.  It left a sloper and added another move of tension toward the end.  Maybe hard for 7?
content.protection: Mostly flat landing. 2 to 3 pads usually suffice.
content.location: On The impressive and tall Spear Point Boulder. This route begins on the rail in the center and traverses right to finish on Spearchucker.

content.description: A great route for the dynamic climber. SDS in the middle of the face on a crimp ledge. Make a big move right to anither ledge and work your way up the right side of the boulder. Top out over the mini-roof.
content.location: Located behind the Ethiopian boulder (on the right in the more open area to the west) in a small alcove between two boulders.

content.description: Start at the slopey ledges about 5.5ish feet up in the middle of the boulder. Throw for the top of the boulder, or Dyno. Fun (but short) boulder!
content.location: Walk west through Africa area, and look for a large boulder with a large right angled crack. The Contact face is on the west side of this boulder.

content.description: This is a decent route located on the Contact boulder. The route starts on the lower right of the face, on a very chalky flat sidepull. It moves left, linking up to the slopey ledge in the center of the face (where 3-2-1 Contact begins). Â Sit down start!
content.location: When you reach the area where the largest boulder is, Africa Boulder (after walking over a boulder in the ground, look right and you will likely see the boulder. It has a crack on the right side of the face (not to be confused with the boulder with the huge crack from bottom left to upper right). Will upload photo soon!
